objinfo.printdate: c. 1804-05The characteristics of the color printing indicate that this impression is the second one printed c. 1804-05. The first impression in that printing session is *God Judging Adam* in the Tate Collection (Butlin 294).
objinfo.medium: color printed relief etching(?) with water color and pen and ink additions to the impressionThe printing matrix would appear to be a copperplate etched in relief. Evidence for this is provided by indentations around some of the printed areas representing God in the impression in the Philadelphia Museum of Art (Butlin 296); and letters blind-embossed lower right, probably created by a platemaker's mark, visible in this impression.

provenance.name: Metropolitan Museum of Art
provenance.note: Perhaps acquired by Blake's wife, Catherine, upon his death in 1827; perhaps acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Mrs. Blake's death in 1831; the dealer Joseph Hogarth, who offered the print, with the assistance of George Richmond, to John Ruskin c. 1843; at least briefly in Ruskin's possession, but probably returned to Hogarth; Mrs. Alexander Gilchrist by 1863; James S. Inglis by 1892; Mrs. Louis Inglis, who sold the print to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1916.

objnote.p: "God Judging Adam," loosely based on Genesis 3:17-19, embodies Blake's criticism of legalistic tyranny, judgment, and punishment of the sort he also explores through the character of Urizen in the illuminated books of the mid-1790s. God, riding on a fiery chariot, holds his book of laws on his lap and points toward Adam with his extended right arm. Adam's long beard indicates that he has already been marked by mortality.

illustration.illusobjdesc: God, who is old, gowned, and bearded and has long hair, sits on a flaming chariot drawn by two horses with flame-like manes and tails. He extends his right arm, hand, and index finger to point in judgment at the nude and hunched or bowing form of Adam, who stands before him with eyes down and face partly obscured by long, flowing beard. God’s left hand rests on a book or tablet (of laws?) on his lap. God may be holding the horses' reins in his right hand, or a rod, scepter, or fiery beam (?) pointing at Adam. God is backed by a circle or globe of fire; the sky above and to the left is filled with yellow light. Grass, moss, lichens, or some such vegetation may be growing beneath the feet of Adam and the horses.

component.illusobjdesc: God sits on a chariot of flame. He is bearded, gowned, and old, and has long hair. Flames surround him as he faces to the left with his head bent slightly forward and down to look at Adam. His right arm, hand, and index finger are extended to point at Adam, who stands before him; God may also be using his right hand to hold the horses' reins or a flame-colored rod or scepter. His left arm is bent at the elbow, and his left hand rests on the book or tablet on his lap. His bare left foot is visible beneath the hem of his gown, and appears to be resting on a platform of the chariot.
A book or tablet (of laws?) rests on God’s lap.

God may be holding a red, flame-like scepter or rod in his right hand, pointed toward Adam. Alternatively, this line could simply be one of the reins extending to the horses, although the reins are darkly colored elsewhere in the design.

God sits on a chariot that seems to be made mostly of fire. Flames rise upward behind him, sideways beneath his body, and downwards below his foot. The circle or globe behind God is filled with flames; it may be the sun. God’s foot rests on a plinth-like platform of the chariot.

Two horses, facing left, pull the chariot upon which God sits. The front-most horse strides to the left with its front left hoof and back right hoof. The legs of the horse behind it are not pictured. The horses have flame-like manes and tails and are wearing harnesses. One rein extends to the right towards God.

Adam, nude, muscular, and old, stands before God with his shoulders hunched over in a bow, his head bent forward, and his eyes down. This posture suggests reverence and perhaps fear. He has long hair, with a prominent forelock, and his beard obscures the lower part of his face. He faces to the right with his left leg bent behind him, and his left foot poised on tiptoe. He may be striding toward God. His arms (or at least his right arm) are probably bent upward, for his right hand is raised to his forehead and his palms may be together in prayer.
The sky is filled with yellow light.
The reticulations of the color printing suggest that grass, moss, lichens, or some such vegetation may grow beneath the feet of Adam and the horses.
